sect1.title: Void
sect1.para: void is a return-only type declaration indicating the function does not return a value, but the function may still terminate. Therefore, it cannot be part of a union type declaration. Available as of PHP 7.1.0.

note.simpara: Even if a function has a return type of void it will still return a value, this value is always &null;.

sect2.title: Example: Using void Return Type
sect2.para: Here is an example of a function that sends an email. The function has a void return type because it does not return any value.

informalexample.programlisting:
<?php
function sendEmail(string $recipient, string $subject, string $message): void {
    // Here would be the code to send the email
    // mail($recipient, $subject, $message);
    echo "Email sent to $recipient with the subject: $subject\n";
}

// Calling the function
sendEmail("example@domain.com", "Test Subject", "Test Message");
?>

sect2.simpara: This function performs an action (sending an email) but does not return a value, hence the return type is void.
